    % Basic figure setup, for now with no caption control since it's done
    % automatically by Pandoc (which extracts ![](path) syntax from Markdown).
    \usepackage{graphicx}
    % We will generate all images so they have a width \maxwidth. This means
    % that they will get their normal width if they fit onto the page, but
    % are scaled down if they would overflow the margins.
    \makeatletter
    \def\maxwidth{\ifdim\Gin@nat@width>\linewidth\linewidth
    \else\Gin@nat@width\fi}
    \makeatother
    \let\Oldincludegraphics\includegraphics
    % Set max figure width to be 80% of text width, for now hardcoded.
    \renewcommand{\includegraphics}[1]{\Oldincludegraphics[width=.8\maxwidth]{#1}}
    % Ensure that by default, figures have no caption (until we provide a
    % proper Figure object with a Caption API and a way to capture that
    % in the conversion process - todo).
    \usepackage{caption}
    \DeclareCaptionLabelFormat{nolabel}{}
    \captionsetup{labelformat=nolabel}

    \paragraph{2.1 Visualize the univariate distribution of each continuous
feature, and the distribution of the
target.}\label{visualize-the-univariate-distribution-of-each-continuous-feature-and-the-distribution-of-the-target.}

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}77}]:} \PY{n}{continuous} \PY{o}{=} \PY{p}{[}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{tenure}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{MonthlyCharges}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{,} \PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{TotalCharges}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}78}]:} \PY{n}{target} \PY{o}{=} \PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{Churn}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}
\end{Verbatim}

    I notice that some NA values in \texttt{TotalCharges} are coded as blank
spaces and prevent correct parsing of the column to build its histogram.
I code them appropriately before going forward:

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\end{Verbatim}

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
{\color{incolor}In [{\color{incolor}80}]:} \PY{n}{data}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{TotalCharges}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{]} \PY{o}{=} \PY{n}{data}\PY{p}{[}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{l+s+s1}{TotalCharges}\PY{l+s+s1}{\PYZsq{}}\PY{p}{]}\PY{o}{.}\PY{n}{astype}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n+nb}{float}\PY{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

                    Scores
LogisticRegression   1.000

NearestCentroid      0.832
    \end{verbatim}

    
    \textbf{The results have significantly improved for \texttt{SVM} and
\texttt{NearestCentroid} with \texttt{SVM} achieving 100\% accuracy on
the validation sets. \texttt{LogisticRegression} maintains 100\%
accuracy.}

    \textbf{It is very likely that \texttt{SVM} and
\texttt{LogisticRegression} overfit the training data as a whole.}

    \paragraph{2.3 Tune the parameters using GridSearchCV. Do the results
improve?Visualize the performance as function of the parameters for all
three
models.}\label{tune-the-parameters-using-gridsearchcv.-do-the-results-improvevisualize-the-performance-as-function-of-the-parameters-for-all-three-models.}

The best logistic regression validation score is 1.0000

    \end{Verbatim}

    We notice that we get perfect accuracy with a smaller \texttt{C},
probably a better model (simpler), less prone to overfitting than the
default model with parameter \texttt{C=1} - in which regularization
accounts for less in the predictions.

    \textbf{The results for \texttt{LogisticRegression} and \texttt{SVC}
were already optimal. The result for \texttt{NearestCentroid} has also
become optimal. This might very well reflect overfitting although we
need to compare to results on the testing set to confirm this.}

    \paragraph{2.4 Change the cross-validation strategy from `stratified
k-fold' to `kfold' with shuffling. Do theparameters that are found
change? Do they change if you change the random seed of theshuffling? Or
if you change the random state of the split into training and test
data?}\label{change-the-cross-validation-strategy-from-stratified-k-fold-to-kfold-with-shuffling.-do-theparameters-that-are-found-change-do-they-change-if-you-change-the-random-seed-of-theshuffling-or-if-you-change-the-random-state-of-the-split-into-training-and-test-data}

    \textbf{The parameters have not changed.} This provides a bit of
evidence against overfitting.

    \paragraph{2.5 Visualize the coefficients for LogisticRegression and
Linear Support Vector Machines usinghyper-parameters that performed well
in the
grid-search.}\label{visualize-the-coefficients-for-logisticregression-and-linear-support-vector-machines-usinghyper-parameters-that-performed-well-in-the-grid-search.}

    \begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

                                  \PY{n}{LogisticRegression}\PY{p}{(}\PY{n}{C}\PY{o}{=}\PY{o}{.}\PY{l+m+mi}{1}\PY{p}{,}
